Webpack App

Webpack config

Using the webpack.config.js file, we can globally set the mode which allows us to remove that from the script in the package.json.

We can also set where webpack compiles its assets from and where it sends those built assets as well as the filename which by default is main.js

The following is a simple .config file which supports what is mentioned above:

const path = require('path')
module.exports = {
mode: 'development',
entry: path.resolve(__dirname, 'src/index.js'),
output: {
path: path.resolve(__dirname, 'dist'),
filename: 'build.js'
},
}

If we want to include code splitting, we can change the entry option to an object and use its name parameter as the filename output using the bracket syntax. See the updated .config below:

entry: {
bundle: path.resolve(__dirname, 'src/index.js'),
},
output: {
path: path.resolve(__dirname, 'dist'),
filename: '[name].js'
},

Loaders

Loaders allow for images, scss to be compiled with the webpack build.

To include loaders in the config, we need to install the appropriate modules. Run the following install:

npm i -D sass style-loader css-loader sass-loader

We can try to import a .scss file into our index.js, but webpack will thow an error:

ERROR in ./src/styles/main.scss 1:0
Module parse failed: Unexpected character '@' (1:0)
You may need an appropriate loader to handle this file type, currently no loaders are configured to process this file. See https://webpack.js.org/concepts#loaders

So in order to build sass files we need an extra module object in our webpack config file.

module: {
rules: [
{
test: /\.scss$/,
use: ['style-loader', 'css-loader', 'sass-loader'],
},

],
},

Plugins

Simple setup

Al that is needed for a simple webpack setup which will allow us to use javascript modules, is the following:

  1. Run:
    npm init -y
    To create the package.json.
    and install webpack and webpack-cli as a dev dependency:
    npm i webpack webpack-cli -D
  2. Then in the package.json, replace the existing script there with this:
    "build": "webpack --mode production"
    After running that command webpack will compile exerything inside the index.js file and its imported modules (including node_modules) to a dist directory as the file main.js.
    Webpack expects the index.js file to be within an src directory.
